issues.title: ILoggingBuilder on part of Logging.Abstractions
issues.body: Any reason why ILoggingBuilder.cs is not part of the Logging.Abstractions namespace but rather a part of the implementation assembly?

issues.title: Windows EventLog package for .NET Core
issues.body:
The Windows compatibility pack provides a preview [Windows EventLog](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Diagnostics.EventLog/) package for .NET Core/.NET Standard 2.0. Are there any plans to integrate this package in the existing EventLog implementation? I successfully did so locally and it compiles cleanly. 

However, the compatibility package is still in preview. Are there any timeframes for this?

issues.title: Consider moving BatchingLogging to Logging
issues.body:
Batching logging is nice implementation for concurrent and heavy log messages. It would be useful to put this implementation outside Azure logging. 
Then it would be easy reused for File logging, database and other external providers.

issues.title: Flaky test: TestLogWritesToGlobalLogFile
issues.body:
As seen [here](http://aspnetci/viewLog.html?buildId=367315&tab=buildResultsDiv&buildTypeId=XPlat_Windows_Win10Universe#testNameId-1444600581581225772).

```
System.IO.IOException : The directory is not empty.
```
Seems like something about our cleanup here isn't robust enough.

issues.title: AppService logging to BlobStorage can lead to memory exhaustion
issues.body: We recently updated our web app to Asp.Net Core 2.0 (from 1.1). After we deployed this change to AppService in Azure, we started to see high memory usage and OutOfMemoryExceptions after a while (a few hours). Only a restart would temporarily fix the problem. Here is what we were seeing with App Service diagnostics: After some time we noticed that the Blob Storage application logging level was set to "Verbose": ![screen shot 2017-12-06 at 10 22 03 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46972/33688080-3fbddb7e-daa8-11e7-9c86-e58419e39510.png) This was not intentional, so we reverted the level to "Warning". After this change, the memory problem disappeared. So my question is: Is this a bug, or is this by design? The logging level should not have been set to "Verbose" in the first place and this was our error. But clearly this problem didn't exist with Asp.Net Core 1.1 Thank you.

issues.title: Don't use Task.Factory.StartNew, it's dangerous
issues.body:
Using `Task.Factory.StartNew`, without specifying a task scheduler or
denying child attach or any of a half dozen non-obvious flags/parameters
can cause undesired behavior from the task. This hidden behavior causes
any uses of the console logger in Xamarin Workbooks to hijack the main thread,
preventing further execution, regardless of the workbook platform (.NET Core,
iOS, Desktop .NET all exhibit this issue at slightly different points).

See this article for some of the dangers of `Task.Factory.StartNew`,
particularly around not using `DenyChildAttach`, and why `LongRunning`
is unnecessary: https://blog.stephencleary.com/2013/08/startnew-is-dangerous.html.
This PR replaces `Task.Factory.StartNew` with `Task.Run`, which is semantically more
correct, functionally equivalent, and more importantly, does not cause any main
thread hijacking.

Would be nice if this could make it into 2.1.0. :)

issues.title: Remove/obsolete AzureAppServicesDiagnosticsSettings.OutputTemplate
issues.body: It's not used since we moved off Serilog.

issues.title: Proposal: LogLevel triggered buffered LoggerDecorator
issues.body:
We had a situation, where our normal logging level of warning did not provide enough information, but the information logs would show the information. Unfortunately information logs will generate lots more of output, which might or might not be useful.

So my proposal is that there should be a logger which will:
 - Create a Log-Buffer for every incomming request
 - Write into that buffer
 - when an log message of level x (e.g. ERROR) is sent to the logger, it will flush all messages of level y to whatever Logger is decorated by the buffered-log-level-triggered-LoggerDecorator.
 - when no log message of level x is received, all messages are silently discarded.

X and Y could be configured as well as the logger it decorates.

issues.title: Warning C4691 when building a C++/CLI executable
issues.body:
As the title reads, I am attempting to utilize the logging library from a C++/CLI (.NET Framework 4.6) executable.  Original MSDN thread with artifacts [here](https://social.msdn.microsoft.com/Forums/vstudio/en-US/fae48caa-7746-4c8f-9c44-839bd23ed128/warning-c4691-when-building-a-ccli-executable-referencing-microsoftextensionslogging-via-nuget?forum=vcgeneral)

It actually works quite well, but I am experiencing concerning warnings inclusive of the following:

```
>c:\projects\ucpro\application\ucpront\logging.h(33): warning C4691: 'System::Exception': type referenced was expected in unreferenced assembly 'System.Runtime', type defined in current translation unit used instead
>c:\projects\ucpro\application\ucpront\logging.h(33): note: This diagnostic occurred while importing type 'Microsoft::Extensions::Logging::ILogger ' from assembly 'Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions, Version=1.1.2.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=adb9793829ddae60'.
>c:\projects\ucpro\application\ucpront\logging.h(33): warning C4691: 'System::Func': type referenced was expected in unreferenced assembly 'System.Runtime', type defined in current translation unit used instead
>c:\projects\ucpro\application\ucpront\logging.h(33): note: This diagnostic occurred while importing type 'Microsoft::Extensions::Logging::ILogger ' from assembly 'Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions, Version=1.1.2.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=adb9793829ddae60'.
```

As you can see in the warnings, the logging package versions are 1.1.2

Exact steps for recreating the issue are outlined in the MSDN thread, but to summarize, merely opening and compiling SW-132 project in [SW-132v2](https://www.dropbox.com/s/9261ina8p4gyce1/SW-132v2.zip?dl=0) exhibits the issue.

issues.title: Fix config loading to be case insensitive
issues.body:
Hi,

this PR files an issue with loading filter configuration. The configuration section `LogLevel` and the category name as well were read case-sensitive while the Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration is case-insensitive, which leads to an unexpected behavior.

see:
https://github.com/aspnet/Logging/blob/71e619a5599af7bdf903061ac011ed2c6f62a744/src/Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Configuration/LoggerFilterConfigureOptions.cs#L33

https://github.com/aspnet/Logging/blob/71e619a5599af7bdf903061ac011ed2c6f62a744/src/Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Configuration/LoggerFilterConfigureOptions.cs#L58

Cheers,
 Andy

Consider demystifying exceptions by default in Console logger
issues.body:
See https://github.com/benaadams/Ben.Demystifier

Using that library may be tricky but we could share code or something. Async stack traces are so bad and this makes them much much cleaner

issues.title: Adding extensions to defer calculation of the log message
issues.body:
Logging can add quite a overhead if you need to put expensive information on the message, or if you ommit them may affect the purpose of the message.

Spreading conditionals based on the level can bloat the code easily.

Using a lambda, the expensive operations don't affect the production code and solve the above issues.

issues.title: Discussion: Extended support for custom ILogger-s
issues.body:
Hi.

I'm looking for ways to extend the capabilities of the ILogger interface. Here is the full scenario I'm seeking support for.

I have an ILogger implementation for AppInsights's TelemetryClient. The ILogger.Log<TState> method implementation calls into the TrackTrace method of the underlying TelemetryClient instance. **Beside that, I also want to have a mechanism to expose the telemetryClient.LogMetric API**.

My proposal is to change the ILoggerFactory.CreateLogger(string categoryName) method to be generic, maybe like the below one:
    **`T CreateLogger<T>(string categoryName) where T : ILogger;`**

I understand this would require some internal changes in the LoggerFactory class, but this would enable custom interface based telemetry support. In other words, I would be able to define a new interface:

```
    public interface IExtendedLogger : ILogger
    {
        void LogMetric(string metricName, double value);
    }
```
and get an instance for that still using the ILoggerFactory as usual.
The TelemetryClient wrapping logger would then implement this interface instead, and would allow me to properly expose both LogMetric and Log methods.

So the classes using ILogger, which need to also be able to use the new API will need to be updated to use IExtendedLogger instead. But with that only change (on the consumer/client side) my existing logging code would just work as is, plus I would be able to also use the new LogMetric API wherever I need to.

Anyway, bringing this up for discussion - would be glad to hear your feedback on this.

issues.title: CreateLogger<T>() design change proposal
Context method and Always trace level
ConsoleLoggerProvider thread leaks
issues.body:
Hi I am on the stratis platform team (we are developing the blockchain in C#).  
Just wanted to let you know that we have an issue where when we create two instances of ConsoleLoggerProvider we observed thread leaks (thread count grows indefinitely until the system halts)

See an print out form the diagnostics tool:

```
Not Flagged		505824	290	Worker Thread	<No Name>	System.Private.CoreLib.dll!System.Threading.SemaphoreSlim.WaitUntilCountOrTimeout	Normal

 	 	 	 	 	 	System.Private.CoreLib.dll!System.Threading.SemaphoreSlim.WaitUntilCountOrTimeout(int millisecondsTimeout, uint startTime, System.Threading.CancellationToken cancellationToken)	 
 	 	 	 	 	 	System.Private.CoreLib.dll!System.Threading.SemaphoreSlim.Wait(int millisecondsTimeout, System.Threading.CancellationToken cancellationToken)	 
 	 	 	 	 	 	System.Collections.Concurrent.dll!System.Collections.Concurrent.BlockingCollection<Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console.Internal.LogMessageEntry>.TryTakeWithNoTimeValidation(out Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console.Internal.LogMessageEntry item, int millisecondsTimeout, System.Threading.CancellationToken cancellationToken, System.Threading.CancellationTokenSource combinedTokenSource)	 
 	 	 	 	 	 	System.Collections.Concurrent.dll!System.Collections.Concurrent.BlockingCollection<Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console.Internal.LogMessageEntry>.GetConsumingEnumerable(System.Threading.CancellationToken cancellationToken)	 
 	 	 	 	 	 	Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console.dll!Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console.Internal.ConsoleLoggerProcessor.ProcessLogQueue()	 
 	 	 	 	 	 	Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console.dll!Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console.Internal.ConsoleLoggerProcessor.ProcessLogQueue(object state)	 
 	 	 	 	 	 	System.Private.CoreLib.dll!System.Threading.ExecutionContext.Run(System.Threading.ExecutionContext executionContext, System.Threading.ContextCallback callback, object state)	 
 	 	 	 	 	 	System.Private.CoreLib.dll!System.Threading.Tasks.Task.ExecuteWithThreadLocal(ref System.Threading.Tasks.Task currentTaskSlot)	 
 	 	 	 	 	 	System.Private.CoreLib.dll!System.Threading.ExecutionContext.Run(System.Threading.ExecutionContext executionContext, System.Threading.ContextCallback callback, object state)	 
```
Here is the code that caused the issue (this was the second instance of ConsoleLoggerProvider.  
https://github.com/stratisproject/StratisBitcoinFullNode/blob/b9069a1fed5b776b11ac82e64595da848f44200a/Stratis.Bitcoin/Utilities/PrefixLogger.cs#L40

Don't set AsyncLocal for scope if not included
issues.body:
Don't disturb the `ExecutionContext` if scopes aren't being used as it wildly increases allocations

Without ConsoleLogger (no changes to AsyncLocal)
![](https://aoa.blob.core.windows.net/aspnet/tasks-action.png)

With ConsoleLogger and no scopes - but not logging anything (changes to AsyncLocal)
![](https://aoa.blob.core.windows.net/aspnet/async-local.png)

You can see the allocations of `Action` and `MoveNextRunner` disproportionately increase; prior to this change

Resolves https://github.com/aspnet/Logging/issues/714

/cc @davidfowl 

You are right @anurse, logging allocations make me sad 😢

issues.title: Don't set AsyncLocal for scope if not included
issues.body:
Adding ConsoleLogger disturbs the `ExecutionContext` even if scopes aren't being used and causes allocations to wildly increase.

Without ConsoleLogger (no-changes to AsyncLocal)
![](https://aoa.blob.core.windows.net/aspnet/tasks-action.png)

With ConsoleLogger and no scopes - but not logging anything to Console (changes to AsyncLocal)
![](https://aoa.blob.core.windows.net/aspnet/async-local.png)

You can see the allocations of `Action` and `MoveNextRunner` disproportionately increase

issues.title: Use EventLog InstanceId instead of (deprecated) eventID to prevent exceptions with IDs > 65535
Question: Is the ConsoleLogger safe to use in production?
issues.body:
I was configuring the logging for a new ASP.NET Core app, and I had the vague memory that the `ConsoleLogger` was not supposed to be used in production. 

Searching around, all I could find was a couple of comments on [this issue](https://github.com/aspnet/IISIntegration/issues/245#issuecomment-238666662) that suggested that a global lock in the `ConsoleLogger` library could cause performance issues. 

Comparing the `ConsoleLogger`  code between 1.0 and 2.0, it looks like a previous `lock()` usage has been removed. 

Does that mean the `ConsoleLogger` is now safe to use in production, or were these comments referring to a different global lock?

Thanks

issues.title: System.Diagnostics.Tracing.EventSource.GenerateManifest throws with LoggingEventSource
issues.body:
This happens with Asp.Net Core 2.0:

When EventSource.GenerateManifest() is called with a LoggingEventSource type as first argument an exception is thrown with message: "Unsupported type ExceptionInfo in event source".

It seems only primitive types are allowed as WriteEvent arguments on the event source.

The code that generates the exception is at line 198 of:
https://github.com/dotnet/coreclr/blob/7ca2692405f255ce4a87d2c3ec263d938cf274fc/src/mscorlib/src/System/Diagnostics/Eventing/EventSource_CoreCLR.cs

I am using a library called [EtwStream](https://github.com/neuecc/EtwStream) to function as an event sink.

issues.title: A mode of Console logger that outputs JSON
issues.body:
This allows an app to output logs to the console that are redirected to a file or read by another process that can then parse the JSON to maintain structured logs.

The canonical example of this is a side-car container on a Docker host. The side car picks up all Docker logs and sends them to an external logging sink, like app insights or sending to an ELK stack.

Fixes #656

Fix issue parsing log message format strings with placeholders containing a format string with a comma ",", such as "{setupTime:#,#}" which uses a custom numeric format string with a group separator. This fix uses the index of the first first comma "," or colon ":" found as the delimiter instead of ignoring the colon ":" if a comma "," was found.

pull_requests.title: Don't use Task.Factory.StartNew, it's dangerous
pull_requests.body:
Using `Task.Factory.StartNew`, without specifying a task scheduler or
denying child attach or any of a half dozen non-obvious flags/parameters
can cause undesired behavior from the task. This hidden behavior causes
any uses of the console logger in Xamarin Workbooks to hijack the main thread,
preventing further execution, regardless of the workbook platform (.NET Core,
iOS, Desktop .NET all exhibit this issue at slightly different points).

See this article for some of the dangers of `Task.Factory.StartNew`,
particularly around not using `DenyChildAttach`, and why `LongRunning`
is unnecessary: https://blog.stephencleary.com/2013/08/startnew-is-dangerous.html.
This PR replaces `Task.Factory.StartNew` with `Task.Run`, which is semantically more
correct, functionally equivalent, and more importantly, does not cause any main
thread hijacking.

Would be nice if this could make it into 2.1.0. :)

issue_comments.body: There are some capabilities for ETW that you want to consider which make the trace usable in production. For e.g. correlation is one concept that you want to bake in early if you do care about it. Implementing correlation as a trace specific implementation might prove harder and so having the abstraction actually support them might be something worth considering early on.
/cc @saggysanctum to understand the impact on your work
Postponed until we can figure out how to do this without breaking EF.

This also contains a reference to OWIN: 

https://github.com/aspnet/Logging/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.Framework.Logging/ILogger.cs#L15
@davidfowl instead of or in addition to aspnetcore50?
Addition to. I'm going to do a sweep to clean up all repos later

@davidfowl I just did the minimal change for now (rename net45 to aspnet50). This is all we really need on EF to move forward. Will this break dependent repos that still target net45? If so, I'll just wait for your sweep.
You would probably implement this with an `ILoggerProvider` that goes async using fire and forget (`async void`)
Tested it, and this breaks dependents that still target net45. I'll wait for the sweep.
The NLog provider here is just a sample, not production code. We don't intend to ship this ever.

Specifically, in this interface: https://github.com/aspnet/Logging/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.Framework.Logging.Interfaces/ILogger.cs

`WriteCore` needs to be focused on just _writing_ log messages. It should not need to return a `bool` to indicate success or enabled status. We should add a new `IsEnabled` method (not sure if it needs the severity param...) to check specifically whether the log is enabled.
While we're at it, should we call WriteCore Write/Log?

commit_comments.body: Until we differentiate between net45 on CLR vs KLR, this breaks Desktop/MSBuild projects. NuGet is going to resolve the net45 Logging assembly which contains AssemblyNeutral types which can't be found at runtime on the CLR.
It's also broken on KLR if I have a net45 project that references a portable project compiled against the portable version of Logging.
Ummm no
lowercase s
sealed? wut
@pranavkm suggested I make it sealed, though I'm not sure what class would try to inherit from this.
Isn't being private enough in this case? I'm not sure we used sealed anywhere else.
Sure. I know it is / was one of @Eilon's pet peeves.
Ok, didn't see the diff. The idea would be to make this `private sealed`

Maybe add a bit of summary as to what the intent of this method is

> `Returns a string that represents the <see cref="ILoggerStructure" /> that is used for ...
what's the difference between `private sealed` and `sealed private`?
@pranavkm thats so pointless though. @SonjaKhan it's the same AFAIK
Sorry, I'm an idiot. I thought you had removed the `private` qualifier. What you have works :100:
ok, so I'm still unsure about whether the `sealed` should be included. I'm leaning towards no...

I _prefer_ the `sealed` because it indicates that nowhere else, even within the containing class, is the type derived from. For trivial nested types it doesn't help much with readability. But in a large class that contains many nested types, it can make it significantly easier to read. But if it's done, definitely `private sealed` instead of `sealed private`.
Um, no. This isn't used anywhere outside of the EF repo :smile:
Um, yes. Please use JetBrains.Annotations. :+1:
https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/183
Part of https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/183
This doesn't look right at all. Why are you using the package on all platforms?

hmm. I tried including the package at top level `dependencies` node and it seemed to work - I mean build.cmd completed successfully without build errors. Though I did not see any other sample doing this.

You can't add this dependency, it breaks the repo layering, even in test projects.
/cc @pranavkm
Yeah - plus it looks it's for parsing media type headers - why do we care about that?
Any chance we could not abbreviate this - `BeginScopeImplementation` \ `BeginLoggerScope`  etc?

`Impl` is a fairly common abbreviation considering the full word is super long, so I don't have any particular problem with _that_. The main issue is that the name is so... ugly... :smile: but that's kind of on purpose so far.

This PR is from half a year ago, I don't think that `LogLevel` value existed! The current code at https://github.com/aspnet/Logging/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.Framework.Logging.NLog/NLogLoggerProvider.cs#L67-L71 looks right to me.
Singleton?
ugh really
This needs to go somewhere useful :smile:

review_comments.body: Should be WriteStop, not WriteEnd
Put this on the `NullLogicalOperation` class in a public readonly field. This way if multiple consumers need it they don't all have their own copy

add a k10 configuration so the next guy doesn't have to do it.

`"k10": { }`

+
+        /// <summary>

+        /// <param name="logger">The logger.</param>

+        /// </returns>
+        public static IDisposable WriteStart(this ILogger logger, int eventId, object state, Exception exception, Func<object, Exception, string> formatter)
+        {
+            if (logger == null)
+            {
+                throw new ArgumentNullException("logger");
+            }
+
+            if (!logger.WriteCore(TraceType.Start, eventId, state, exception, formatter))
+            {
+                return NullLogicalOperation.Instance;
+            }
+
+            return new LogicalOperation(logger, eventId, state, exception, formatter);
+        }
+
+        /// <summary>
+        /// The most general form for writing a stop to the log.

+﻿// Copyright (c) Microsoft Open Technologies, Inc. All rights reserved.

+
+using System;
+#if NET45
+using Moq;
+#endif
+using Xunit;
+using Microsoft.Framework.Logging.Infrastructure;
+
+namespace Microsoft.Framework.Logging.Test
+{
+    public class LoggerExtensionsTests
+    {
+#if NET45
+        [Fact]
+        public void WriteStartDisposable_Calls_WriteStop()
+        {
+            // Arrange
+            var message = "xXx 1337m4sterchief117n0sc0p3xX xXx";
+
+            var mockLogger = new Mock<ILogger>();
+
+            mockLogger
+                .Setup(m => m.WriteCore(
+                    TraceType.Start,
+                    0,
+                    message,
+                    null,
+                    It.IsAny<Func<object, Exception, string>>()))
+                .Returns(true)
+                .Verifiable();
+
+            mockLogger
+                .Setup(m => m.WriteCore(
+                    TraceType.Stop,
+                    0,
+                    message,
+                    null,
+                    It.IsAny<Func<object, Exception, string>>()))
+                .Returns(true)
+                .Verifiable();

review_comments.body:
I was wondering about that - which is why I copied the portable target definition in the project.json also...

The assumption there is that if you're not using vnext from EF, and you're not our host, in you'll end up with the PCL version of Microsoft.Framework.Logging.Interfaces that has the interfaces sitting there as plain old types...

I'm hoping that will keep EF working until we sort out the "now ANI works all over the place" questions
